			<title>Scientists shed light on biological roots of individuality</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216174738.htm</link>
			<description>A new study illuminates the biology that guides behavior across different stages of life in worms, and suggests how variations in specific neuromodulators in the developing nervous system may lead to occasional variations.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=JCc6INRWJrY:jngKXs6kCx4:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=JCc6INRWJrY:jngKXs6kCx4:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=JCc6INRWJrY:jngKXs6kCx4:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=JCc6INRWJrY:jngKXs6kCx4:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=JCc6INRWJrY:jngKXs6kCx4:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>

		<item>
			<title>Increasing incidence of rare skin cancer</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216174658.htm</link>
			<description>While it may not be as common as other skin cancers, Merkel cell carcinoma is highly aggressive and often deadly — and according to new research, it’s also becoming more common.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=Bk8Nd4a8odY:hjy-KPl6S7o:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=Bk8Nd4a8odY:hjy-KPl6S7o:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=Bk8Nd4a8odY:hjy-KPl6S7o:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=Bk8Nd4a8odY:hjy-KPl6S7o:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=Bk8Nd4a8odY:hjy-KPl6S7o:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>

		<item>
			<title>Shot may help shield against shingles</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216174656.htm</link>
			<description>Two vaccines are available to help prevent shingles, which can affect anyone who has had chickenpox or the chickenpox vaccine; both diseases are caused by the same virus, which stays in the body after chickenpox clears.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BnOixF_vtjk:z2ZBCsTwD_w:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BnOixF_vtjk:z2ZBCsTwD_w:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BnOixF_vtjk:z2ZBCsTwD_w:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BnOixF_vtjk:z2ZBCsTwD_w:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BnOixF_vtjk:z2ZBCsTwD_w:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>
			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 17:46:56 EST</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216174656.htm</guid>
		</item>
		<item>
			<title>Progress in pursuit of sickle cell cure</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216150341.htm</link>
			<description>Bioengineers use gene editing to correct the mutation responsible for sickle cell disease in up to 40 percent of patients' cells used for lab testing.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=DfUu1qTecdU:NXLKOw9JmH0:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=DfUu1qTecdU:NXLKOw9JmH0:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=DfUu1qTecdU:NXLKOw9JmH0:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=DfUu1qTecdU:NXLKOw9JmH0:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=DfUu1qTecdU:NXLKOw9JmH0:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Cells communicate in a dynamic code</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216150338.htm</link>

		<item>
			<title>Humans will actually react pretty well to news of alien life</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142705.htm</link>
			<description>Hollywood has it wrong. Humans would actually react positively to news of alien life -- intelligent or microbial.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=pFleyzjuMQ8:QxFRyxADoP4:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=pFleyzjuMQ8:QxFRyxADoP4:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=pFleyzjuMQ8:QxFRyxADoP4:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=pFleyzjuMQ8:QxFRyxADoP4:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=pFleyzjuMQ8:QxFRyxADoP4:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>

		</item>
		<item>
			<title>Pilot study in Kenya shows link between chronic pain and glutamate consumption</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142702.htm</link>
			<description>Preliminary research from a small pilot study carried out in Meru, in eastern Kenya, shows a link between chronic pain and consumption of glutamate, a common flavor enhancer found in Western and non-Western diets worldwide.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BKKNO83V8VI:HmFnTtAok0I:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BKKNO83V8VI:HmFnTtAok0I:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BKKNO83V8VI:HmFnTtAok0I:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BKKNO83V8VI:HmFnTtAok0I:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=BKKNO83V8VI:HmFnTtAok0I:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>
			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 14:27:02 EST</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142702.htm</guid>
		</item>
		<item>
			<title>Lab-grown human cerebellar cells yield clues to autism</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142659.htm</link>
			<description>Increasing evidence has linked autism spectrum disorder (ASD) with dysfunction of the brain's cerebellum, but the details have been unclear. In a new study, researchers used stem cell technology to create cerebellar cells known as Purkinje cells from patients with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), a genetic syndrome that often includes ASD-like features.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fMmuqBv9NaM:eo9BWRMkQ9U:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fMmuqBv9NaM:eo9BWRMkQ9U:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fMmuqBv9NaM:eo9BWRMkQ9U:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fMmuqBv9NaM:eo9BWRMkQ9U:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fMmuqBv9NaM:eo9BWRMkQ9U:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>
			<media:thumbnail url="https://www.sciencedaily.com/images/2018/02/180216142659-large.jpg" height="300" width="300" />
			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 14:26:59 EST</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142659.htm</guid>
		</item>
		<item>
			<title>Immune signature predicts asthma susceptibility</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142656.htm</link>
			<description>Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease driven by the interplay of genetics, environmental factors and a diverse cast of immune cells. Researchers have now identified a subset of T cells, whose frequency serves as early childhood immune signature that predicts the risk of developing asthma later on.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=TgpIiryAw44:Py9TIcugVHY:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=TgpIiryAw44:Py9TIcugVHY:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=TgpIiryAw44:Py9TIcugVHY:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=TgpIiryAw44:Py9TIcugVHY:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=TgpIiryAw44:Py9TIcugVHY:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>
			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 14:26:56 EST</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="true">https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142656.htm</guid>
		</item>
		<item>
			<title>Drug transfer tested using placenta-on-a-chip</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142653.htm</link>
			<description>Researchers have demonstrated the feasibility of their 'organ-on-a-chip' platform in studying how drugs are transported across the human placental barrier.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fPsNP2Lcc7w:COD0MkwUbxQ:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fPsNP2Lcc7w:COD0MkwUbxQ:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fPsNP2Lcc7w:COD0MkwUbxQ:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fPsNP2Lcc7w:COD0MkwUbxQ:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=fPsNP2Lcc7w:COD0MkwUbxQ:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>
</div></description>

			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 14:26:53 EST</pubDate>

		<item>
			<title>Link between hallucinations and dopamine not such a mystery, finds study</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142646.htm</link>
			<description>Researchers have found that people with schizophrenia who experience auditory hallucinations tend to hear what they expect, an exaggerated version of a perceptual distortion that is common among other people without hallucinations. The researchers found that elevated dopamine could make some patients rely more on expectations, which could then result in hallucinations.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>While a baby was still attached via the umbilical cord, doctors attached a pacemaker to the baby's heart</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216142635.htm</link>
			<description>Researchers completed the first-ever EXIT (Ex Utero Intrapartum Treatment) to ventricular pacing procedure. The patient, a 36-week fetus with complete atrioventricular block and cardiac dysfunction, was at high risk of pre-term death. While attached to its mother via umbilical cord, the baby received a temporary pacemaker, which stabilized its dangerously low and irregular heart rate and ensured enough blood flow from the heart to the rest of its body for delivery.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=p3u7bPF5aaM:oVjCJuKjatA:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=p3u7bPF5aaM:oVjCJuKjatA:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=p3u7bPF5aaM:oVjCJuKjatA:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=p3u7bPF5aaM:oVjCJuKjatA:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=p3u7bPF5aaM:oVjCJuKjatA:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216113910.htm</link>
			<description>Teens work very hard to create a favorable online image through careful selection of which photos, activities and links to post on Facebook and Instagram, according to a recent study. 			<title>Increased stress on fathers leads to brain development changes in offspring</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216110547.htm</link>
			<description>New research in mice has found that a father's stress affects the brain development of his offspring. This stress changes the father's sperm, which can then alter the brain development of the child. This new research provides a much better understanding of the key role that fathers play in the brain development of offspring.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>High levels of microplastics found in Northwest Atlantic fish</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180216110513.htm</link>
			<description>A new study finds 73 percent of mesopelagic fish caught in the Northwest Atlantic had microplastics in their stomachs -- one of the highest levels globally. Typically living at depths of 200-1,000 meters, these fish could spread microplastic pollution throughout the marine ecosystem, by carrying microplastics from the surface down to deeper waters. They are also prey for fish eaten by humans, meaning that microplastics could indirectly contaminate our food supply.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=T4rUbNZ6QCY:HrGVgkBYD-U:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=T4rUbNZ6QCY:HrGVgkBYD-U:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=T4rUbNZ6QCY:HrGVgkBYD-U:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=T4rUbNZ6QCY:HrGVgkBYD-U:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=T4rUbNZ6QCY:HrGVgkBYD-U:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Mouse and human kidney development compared</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215180318.htm</link>
			<description>Three new research articles compare human and mouse kidney development to identify shared and novel features. The studies revealed deep conservation of certain processes, but also significant differences in gene expression during kidney development, as well as in the timing, scale, organization, and molecular profile of key cell types and cell structures.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>Why do healthy children die from the flu? Study offers new insights</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215165511.htm</link>
			<description>With this year’s severe flu season, one statistic is especially chilling. Each year, around 50 percent of all children under 5 years old who die from the flu were previously healthy. Adults who die from the flu, on the other hand, typically had a medical condition that increased their risk of mortality. A new study offers new insights as to why healthy children are much more vulnerable. It also opens new opportunities for treatment.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rV-uBLeF35s:ekVkAyeI93c:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rV-uBLeF35s:ekVkAyeI93c:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rV-uBLeF35s:ekVkAyeI93c:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rV-uBLeF35s:ekVkAyeI93c:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rV-uBLeF35s:ekVkAyeI93c:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Hearing loss is common after infant heart surgery</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215144617.htm</link>
			<description>Children who have heart surgery as infants are at risk for hearing loss, coupled with associated risks for language, attention and cognitive problems, by age four. In a cohort of 348 preschoolers who survived cardiac surgery, researchers found hearing loss in about 21 percent, a rate 20 times higher than is found in the general population. This underscores the importance of early hearing evaluations in young children who undergo heart surgery.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=UrnjdPWko0A:b703AWyoSs0:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=UrnjdPWko0A:b703AWyoSs0:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=UrnjdPWko0A:b703AWyoSs0:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=UrnjdPWko0A:b703AWyoSs0:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=UrnjdPWko0A:b703AWyoSs0:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Genetics makes Asians, Europeans susceptible to dengue shock syndrome</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141846.htm</link>
			<description>As globalization and climate change spread tropical diseases around the globe, not all populations are equally susceptible to infection. Gene variants common in people of Asian and European ancestry, for instance, make them more prone than those of African origin to developing severe dengue shock syndrome, according to a new study.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>Immune system simulation shows need for multi-target treatments for sepsis</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141838.htm</link>

		<item>
			<title>CRISPR-based diagnostic tool advanced, miniature paper test developed</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141753.htm</link>
			<description>The team that first unveiled the rapid, inexpensive, highly sensitive CRISPR-based diagnostic tool called SHERLOCK has greatly enhanced the tool's power to work with a miniature paper test, similar to a pregnancy test, allowing rapid and simple detection in any setting. Additional features greatly expand both the breadth and sensitivity of the diagnostic information, including the ability to detect multiple targets at once and quantify the amount of target in a sample.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>CRISPR scissors, Cas12a, enables cutting-edge diagnostics</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141735.htm</link>
			<description>Utilizing an unsuspected activity of the CRISPR-Cas12a protein, researchers created a simple diagnostic system called DETECTR to analyze cells, blood, saliva, urine and stool to detect genetic mutations, cancer and antibiotic resistance and also diagnose bacterial and viral infections. The scientists discovered that when Cas12a binds its double-stranded DNA target, it indiscriminately chews up all single-stranded DNA. They then created reporter molecules attached to single-stranded DNA to signal when Cas12a finds its target.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=3NhCG4puE60:EUapK9JzIqY:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=3NhCG4puE60:EUapK9JzIqY:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=3NhCG4puE60:EUapK9JzIqY:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=3NhCG4puE60:EUapK9JzIqY:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=3NhCG4puE60:EUapK9JzIqY:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

			<title>Eating yogurt may reduce cardiovascular disease risk</title>

		<item>
			<title>Birds and primates share brain cell types linked to intelligence</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141719.htm</link>
			<description>In a new study scientists show that some neurons in bird brains form the same kind of circuitry and have the same molecular signature as cells that enable connectivity between different areas of the mammalian neocortex. The researchers found that alligators share these cell types as well, suggesting that while mammal, bird and reptile brains have very different anatomical structures, they operate using the same shared set of brain cell types.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rq19FgUAntE:3mLY5yEa6o4:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rq19FgUAntE:3mLY5yEa6o4:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rq19FgUAntE:3mLY5yEa6o4:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rq19FgUAntE:3mLY5yEa6o4:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=rq19FgUAntE:3mLY5yEa6o4:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215141649.htm</link>
			<description>Lesbian and gay youth showed significantly less psychological distress and were buffered against the negative effects of bullying and victimization when they were in a relationship than when they were not, reports a new study. 			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215125026.htm</link>
			<description>Induced pluripotent stem cells, or iPS cells, are a keystone of regenerative medicine. 		<item>
			<title>OCD treatment could someday start with a brain scan</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110522.htm</link>
			<description>Researchers have developed a way to use brain scans and machine learning — a form of artificial intelligence — to predict whether people with OCD will benefit from cognitive behavior therapy. The technique could help improve the overall success rate of cognitive behavioral therapy, and it could enable therapists to tailor treatment to each patient.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=ggXDPUKyB2c:cRhqm7eDflQ:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=ggXDPUKyB2c:cRhqm7eDflQ:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=ggXDPUKyB2c:cRhqm7eDflQ:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=ggXDPUKyB2c:cRhqm7eDflQ:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=ggXDPUKyB2c:cRhqm7eDflQ:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>A new class of drug to treat herpes simplex virus infection</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110339.htm</link>
			<description>For patients with the herpes simplex-1 virus (HSV-1), there are just a handful of drugs available to treat the painful condition that can affect the eyes, mouth and genitals. If patients develop resistance to these drugs, there are even fewer choices left to treat the infection, which lasts for life. Researchers have now identified a small drug molecule that can clear the HSV-1 infection in the cells of the cornea -- the clear outer layer of the eyeball -- and works completely differently than the currently-available drugs, making it a promising potential option for patients who have developed resistance.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=dTajMUQeX2U:OtORRj8aM3c:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=dTajMUQeX2U:OtORRj8aM3c:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=dTajMUQeX2U:OtORRj8aM3c:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=dTajMUQeX2U:OtORRj8aM3c:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=dTajMUQeX2U:OtORRj8aM3c:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110337.htm</link>

		<item>
			<title>Asthma medication linked to infertility in women</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110043.htm</link>
			<description>Women with asthma who only use short-acting asthma relievers take longer to become pregnant than other women, according to international research.<div class="feedflare">

		<item>
			<title>Did humans domesticate themselves?</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110041.htm</link>
			<description>Human ‘self-domestication’ is a hypothesis that states that among the driving forces of human evolution, humans selected their companions depending on who had a more pro-social behavior. Researchers have found new genetic evidence for this evolutionary process.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=gQRstbbplIo:Es7DGiMEEMI:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=gQRstbbplIo:Es7DGiMEEMI:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=gQRstbbplIo:Es7DGiMEEMI:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=gQRstbbplIo:Es7DGiMEEMI:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=gQRstbbplIo:Es7DGiMEEMI:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Strategy in the blink of an eye</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215110039.htm</link>
			<description>If a brief event in our surroundings is about to happen it is probably better not to blink during that moment. Researchers found that humans unconsciously trade off the loss of information during a blink with the physiological urge to blink.<div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=YdCXptctzD0:-tVMGdkVDrI:Gqkty0xVXF4"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Gqkty0xVXF4" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=YdCXptctzD0:-tVMGdkVDrI:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=YdCXptctzD0:-tVMGdkVDrI:qj6IDK7rITs"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=qj6IDK7rITs" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=YdCXptctzD0:-tVMGdkVDrI:uY-AgU320Y0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=uY-AgU320Y0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://feeds.sciencedaily.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?a=YdCXptctzD0:-tVMGdkVDrI:Ue2SbndxCZY"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/sciencedaily/top_news/top_health?d=Ue2SbndxCZY" border="0"></img></a>

		<item>
			<title>Male and female brain rhythms show differences</title>
			<link>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/02/180215105949.htm</link>
			<description>The electric brain signals, measured by using EEG, of males and females show differences. The difference can't be detected by visual inspection, not even by the trained eye of a neurologist. A 'deep learning' computer is able to find it.<div class="feedflare">
